title: Practical Daily Maintenance Handbook: Help You Find Answers and Fix Common Issues
content:
I. Appliance Maintenance: Common Malfunctions & Solutions

Appliances are the most frequently used devices at home. Minor issues with refrigerators, washing machines, air conditioners, ovens, etc., are common, and you can easily fix them by identifying the root cause.

(A) Refrigerator: Poor Cooling, Loud Noise, Water Leakage

Issue 1: Refrigerator Not Cooling or Poor Cooling Performance

 

Common Causes: Aging door seal, dusty condenser, low refrigerant, faulty thermostat

Troubleshooting & Solutions:

Check the door seal first: Open the refrigerator door, clamp a piece of paper between the door and the frame, then close the door and pull the paper. If it comes out easily, the door seal is aging. Remove the seal, clean it with soapy water (to remove oil stains), and replace it with a same-model seal if it’s severely aged (available online by searching for the refrigerator brand + model).

Inspect the condenser: If the condenser (metal grid) at the back or bottom of the refrigerator is covered in dust, it will affect heat dissipation and reduce cooling efficiency. Disconnect the power, then use a soft-bristled brush to clean along the direction of the cooling fins—avoid using a damp cloth (to prevent rust).

If cooling is still poor after cleaning: It may be due to low refrigerant or a faulty thermostat. Adding refrigerant requires professional assistance (avoid DIY to prevent leakage). For a faulty thermostat, try turning the temperature control knob to the "Max Cool" setting. If it still doesn’t work, replace it with a thermostat of the same specification (pay attention to voltage and model matching when purchasing).

 

Issue 2: Loud Noise During Refrigerator Operation

 

Common Causes: Unlevel placement, loose compressor foot pads, misaligned internal shelves or drawers

Solutions:

Use a spirit level to check the refrigerator’s base. If it’s unlevel, adjust the adjustable feet at the bottom to ensure all four corners touch the ground.

Disconnect the power, open the refrigerator’s rear cover, and check the foot pads under the compressor. Tighten loose pads with a wrench; if the pads are aged (hardened or cracked), replace them with new rubber pads (rubber offers better shock absorption).

Check the interior: Ensure shelves are not misaligned and drawers are fully pushed in. Adjust them to the correct position to avoid vibration-induced noise during operation.

 

Issue 3: Water Leakage from the Refrigerator Base

 

Common Causes: Overflowing drip pan, clogged drain pipe, excessive condensation in the fridge compartment

Troubleshooting Steps:

Locate the drip pan first: It’s usually under the compressor at the bottom of the refrigerator. Pull out the pan, empty the water, rinse it with clean water (wipe off dirt with a soft cloth if needed), and put it back.

If the drip pan is empty: The drain pipe may be clogged. There is usually a small drain hole at the back of the fridge compartment. Gently insert a thin wire (with a small hook bent at the end) to clear ice or dirt inside; you can also pour a small amount of warm water (avoid high temperatures) to unclog the pipe.

Excessive condensation in the fridge: Check if the door is properly sealed (refer to the door seal check method). If the door doesn’t close tightly, cold air leakage will cause more condensation. Adjust the door seal or closing force promptly.

(B) Washing Machine: No Spinning, No Water Inlet, Vibration During Spin Cycle

Issue 1: Washing Machine Not Spinning

 

Common Causes: Unbalanced laundry load, clogged drain, faulty spin motor, untriggered safety switch

Troubleshooting Process:

Check the laundry first: If there is too little laundry or clothes are tangled, the machine will trigger a safety mechanism to stop spinning. Open the lid, shake out the clothes, place them evenly in the drum (or impeller), and restart the spin cycle.

Inspect drainage: The machine needs to drain water before spinning. If the drain is clogged, water can’t exit, preventing spinning. Turn off the power, locate the drain hose at the back of the machine, remove it, and clear debris with a thin stick. Also, check the filter bag (at the bottom of the tub for top-loaders, below the front panel for front-loaders), remove it, and clean out hair and debris.

Check the safety switch: A loose safety switch (triggered when the lid is closed) can cause spinning failure. Open the lid, clean the switch contacts with a cotton swab (to remove oxidation), and replace the switch if it still doesn’t work (ensure it matches the washing machine model).

 

Issue 2: Washing Machine Not Filling with Water

 

Common Causes: Faucet not open, clogged inlet hose, faulty inlet valve, defective water level switch

Solutions:

Basic check: Ensure the faucet is fully open and the inlet hose is not kinked (kinks in the hose of front-loaders can block water flow).

Clean the inlet hose: Turn off the faucet, disconnect the inlet hose, and check the filters at both ends (where the hose connects to the faucet and machine). Rinse away sediment if clogged, then reattach the hose.

Faulty inlet valve: If water still doesn’t enter after the above steps, the inlet valve may be defective. Disconnect the power, use a multimeter to measure the valve’s resistance (normal resistance is approximately 200-300 ohms). If the resistance is 0 or infinite, replace the valve with the same model.

(C) Air Conditioner: No Cooling, Blowing Hot Air, Water Leakage

Issue 1: Air Conditioner Not Cooling (Summer)

 

Common Causes: Dirty air filter, poor outdoor unit heat dissipation, refrigerant leakage, faulty compressor

Troubleshooting Steps:

Clean the air filter: Open the indoor unit’s panel, remove the filter, rinse it with clean water (add a small amount of neutral detergent for heavy oil stains), let it dry, and reinstall it (clean every 2-3 weeks).

Inspect the outdoor unit: If the outdoor unit is covered in debris (e.g., leaves, dust), exposed to direct sunlight, or has limited surrounding space, heat dissipation will be affected. Clean debris from the unit’s surface and ensure at least 1 meter of space around it for ventilation. For intense summer sunlight, install a sunshade (avoid full coverage to prevent blocked ventilation).

Refrigerant leakage: If cooling is still poor after cleaning and the outdoor unit makes less noise than usual, refrigerant may be leaking. Contact a professional to detect and repair the leak, then recharge the refrigerant (avoid DIY—incorrect type or amount can damage the unit).

 

Issue 2: Water Leakage from the Indoor AC Unit (Dripping)

 

Common Causes: Clogged drain pan, aging drain pipe, tilted indoor unit installation

Solutions:

Clean the drain pan: Disconnect the power, open the indoor unit’s panel, locate the drain pan (plastic pan at the bottom of the indoor unit), wipe away standing water or dirt with a soft cloth, and check if the pan’s drain hole is clogged—clear it with a thin wire.

Inspect the drain pipe: Check if the drain pipe (connected to the outdoor unit) is aged or cracked (especially for AC units used for over 5 years). Replace cracked pipes with PVC ones (more durable). Ensure the pipe has a slight slope to prevent water backflow.

 

II. Electronic Device Maintenance: High-Frequency Issues with Phones, Laptops, Tablets

Electronic device malfunctions are often related to charging, screens, or systems. Most minor issues can be troubleshot independently to avoid unnecessary repair costs.

(A) Smartphone: Slow Charging, Unresponsive Screen, Fast Battery Drain

Issue 1: Slow Charging (or No Charging)

 

Common Causes: Damaged charger/cable, clogged charging port, aging battery, high background app usage

Troubleshooting & Solutions:

Replace the charger/cable: Test with another original charger (same brand, same wattage) and cable. If fast charging works normally, the original charger or cable is defective—replace it (choose official or reputable third-party products to avoid battery damage).

Clean the charging port: Dust or lint in the port can cause poor contact. Use a toothpick (wrap the tip with tape to avoid scratching metal contacts) and gently insert it into the port to remove debris; you can also use a can of compressed air (for camera lens cleaning) to blow dust out of the port.

Aging battery: If the phone is over 2 years old and has both slow charging and fast drain, the battery may be aged. Check battery health in "Settings > Battery" (supported by most brands). If health is below 80%, replace the battery (official after-sales service is safer than third-party low-quality batteries).

 

Issue 2: Unresponsive Smartphone Screen (No Touch Response)

 

Common Causes: Oil/water on the screen, screen protector issues, system lag, faulty screen hardware

Troubleshooting Steps:

Clean the screen: Wipe the screen with a clean microfiber cloth (or eyeglass cloth) to remove oil and sweat (water causes capacitive screen failure). If the screen is wet, dry it before use.

Check the screen protector: Thick, peeling, or bubbled protectors reduce touch sensitivity. Remove the protector and test—if the screen works normally, replace it with a thin, high-transparency one.

System issues: Force-restart the phone by holding the power and volume buttons (restart methods vary by brand—check the official website). If the screen is still unresponsive, the hardware may be faulty—send it for professional testing.

(B) Laptop: Won’t Turn On, Blue Screen, Unresponsive Keyboard

Issue 1: Laptop Won’t Turn On (No Response When Pressing Power Button)

 

Common Causes: Loose power connection, faulty power adapter, loose RAM module, motherboard issues

Troubleshooting Process (similar for desktops):

Basic check: Ensure the power adapter is properly connected (socket has power, adapter is firmly plugged into the laptop). For laptops with removable batteries, remove the battery, power the laptop directly with the adapter, and press the power button (to rule out a dead battery).

Inspect the power adapter: Check the adapter’s indicator light (if available). If it doesn’t light up, the adapter may be defective. Test with another same-model adapter—replace it if the laptop turns on.

Loose RAM module (for DIY-friendly laptops/desktops): Disconnect the power. For desktops, open the case; for laptops, remove the bottom cover (unscrew screws, discharge static by touching a metal object first). Locate the RAM module, press the clips on both ends to remove it, clean the gold contacts with an eraser (to remove oxidation), reinsert it firmly, and test the laptop.

 

Issue 2: Laptop Blue Screen (Blue Screen with English Error Codes)

 

Common Causes: Software conflicts, incompatible drivers, overheating hardware, hard drive failure

Solutions:

Record the error code: The blue screen displays an English code (e.g., "0x0000007B"). Take a photo and search online for its meaning (most codes correspond to specific issues like driver errors or hard drive problems).

Software/driver issues: If you recently installed new software or drivers, restart the laptop and press F8 (F12 for some brands) to enter "Safe Mode." Uninstall the new software or updated driver, then restart. You can also restore the system (find "Open System Restore" in "Control Panel > Recovery" and select a previous restore point).

Overheating hardware: Clogged vents or non-functional fans cause overheating and blue screens. Turn off the laptop, clean the vents with compressed air, use a cooling pad for laptops, and check if desktop case fans are working—replace non-functional fans.

 

III. Home Fixture Maintenance: Minor Issues with Furniture & Plumbing/Electricals

Minor home fixture issues don’t affect device functionality but impact daily life—simple fixes can resolve them.

(A) Furniture: Stuck Drawers, Loose Cabinet Doors, Wobbly Chair Legs

Issue 1: Stuck Drawer

 

Common Causes: Debris in the track, rusted track, loose track screws

Troubleshooting Steps:

Clean the track: Pull the drawer out as far as possible, check for dust or small objects (e.g., coins, paper scraps) in the track, clean with a brush, and wipe the track with a dry cloth.

Rusted track: If the track is rusted, gently sand the rust with sandpaper, apply a small amount of lubricant (e.g., sewing machine oil, furniture-specific lubricant), and slide the drawer back and forth to distribute the lubricant.

Loose screws: Check the screws connecting the track to the furniture. Tighten loose screws with a screwdriver to secure the track.

 

Issue 2: Loose Cabinet Doors (Wardrobe/Kitchen Cabinets)

 

Common Causes: Loose hinge screws, misaligned hinges, warped door

Solutions:

Adjust hinge screws: Cabinet door hinges usually have 3 screws (to secure the hinge to the cabinet and door). Tighten loose screws with a screwdriver. If the door still doesn’t close tightly, loosen the "adjustment screw" (usually the middle or side screw), gently push the door to the correct position, and retighten the screw.

Warped door: For slightly warped wooden doors (e.g., due to moisture), place a damp cloth over the warped area, iron it at low temperature (avoid high heat to prevent wood damage), and gently press the door to flatten it (only for minor warping).

(B) Plumbing & Electricals: Leaky Faucet, Clogged Toilet, Non-Working Light Bulb

Issue 1: Leaky Faucet (Cartridge Leakage, Joint Leakage)

 

Common Causes: Worn cartridge, aging seal ring, loose joint screws

Troubleshooting Steps:

Turn off the water supply: Close the angle valve corresponding to the faucet (usually under the sink) to prevent water leakage during repair.

Joint leakage: If water leaks from the faucet-pipe joint, gently tighten the joint nut with a wrench (avoid over-tightening to prevent thread damage). If leakage continues, remove the nut, replace the internal seal ring (purchase by joint size), and reinstall.

Cartridge leakage (leakage from the faucet handle): Use a screwdriver to remove the decorative cap on the handle, unscrew the fixing screw, and remove the handle. Use a wrench to remove the cartridge, replace it with a same-model cartridge (pay attention to specifications like single cold/hot-cold and size), and align the cartridge’s slot during installation.

 

Issue 2: Clogged Toilet (Slow Flushing, Rising Water Level)

 

Common Causes: Clogged toilet paper/debris, incorrect plunger use

Solutions:

Use a plunger: Align the plunger with the toilet drain to create a seal, push down and pull up quickly (using air pressure to unclog), and repeat until the water level drops (indicating success).

Use a drain cleaner: If the plunger doesn’t work, pour toilet-specific drain cleaner (follow the instructions—avoid overuse to prevent pipe corrosion), wait 15-20 minutes, pour in warm water (around 40°C, avoid high temperatures to damage the toilet), and flush.

Note: For hard clogs (e.g., toys, keys), do not use drain cleaner. Use a plumbing snake (spring-type), insert it into the drain, rotate and push it forward, and hook out the clog.

 

IV. Pre-Maintenance Must-Knows: Preparation & Precautions

Tool Preparation: Essential Basic Tools

 

A set of screwdrivers (Phillips, flathead—replaceable heads are recommended for different sizes)

Wrenches (adjustable wrench, Allen wrench—for removing joints and nuts)

Pliers (needle-nose pliers, diagonal pliers—for cleaning debris and cutting wires)

Multimeter (for testing circuits and motor faults—digital models are easier for beginners)

Others: Electrical tape (for wrapping wires), soft-bristled brush (for dusting), microfiber cloth (for cleaning screens and door seals)

 

Safety First: Avoid Accidents

 

Disconnect power: Always turn off the power (unplug the cord, switch off the main switch) when maintaining appliances, electronics, or electricals to prevent electric shock.

Water protection: Place a waterproof cloth on the floor when maintaining washing machines or faucets to avoid water damage to circuits. Keep water away from phones and laptops during maintenance.

Do not disassemble blindly: Do not forcefully disassemble complex devices (e.g., outdoor AC units, laptop motherboards) if you can’t troubleshoot the issue—this may damage components. Contact a professional instead.

 

When to Call a Professional? Avoid DIY for These Cases

 

Refrigerant-related issues: Recharging refrigerant for AC units or refrigerators requires professional equipment and skills. DIY can cause leakage, harming the environment and shortening device life.

Electrical faults: If a device emits smoke, has a burning smell, or has charred wires, it indicates a serious electrical issue. Contact an electrician or brand after-sales service to prevent fires.

Core component damage: Replacing core components (e.g., smartphone screen assemblies, laptop motherboards, washing machine motors) is difficult and requires professional tools. DIY may cause secondary damage.

 

This guide covers common daily maintenance scenarios, with detailed troubleshooting steps and solutions. You can find answers based on your specific malfunction. If the issue persists after troubleshooting or involves complex problems, contact a professional maintenance technician promptly to ensure safety and prevent further device damage.
section: Whether it’s home appliances, electronic devices, or basic home fixtures, sudden malfunctions are always a hassle. In fact, many common problems don’t require an immediate call to a professional—you can troubleshoot and fix them yourself. This guide covers high-frequency malfunction scenarios, explaining the causes, solutions, and pre-maintenance precautions to help you resolve maintenance issues quickly.
